Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of Mucosal B Cell Immunity: Novel Roles of IgT+ B Cells in the Control of Host-pathogen Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The mucosal surfaces of vertebrates such as the gut and mouth are inhabited by resident bacteria and also continuously exposed to invading microbes. Throughout evolution, specific types of antibodies have become specialized to protect such mucosal sites. In mammals and birds, immunoglobulin A (IgA) predominates at mucosal surfaces, whereas IgG and IgM provide systemic protection. While fish were thought to be devoid of antibodies dedicated to defend mucosal areas throughout the body, fish with true bones (teleost fish) have been recently found to contain an antibody molecule that is specialized to defend for the skin and gut areas. However, very little is still known about the function of this molecule and the cells producing it. This project proposes further studies on this area which will bring new insights into the evolution of mucosal immunity and its role in host-pathogen interactions in primitive vertebrates. Mucosal areas of fish, including the gut, skin and gills, represent the main areas through which pathogens infect these species. On a broader level beyond new basic scientific knowledge, these studies will benefit society by contributing to the aquaculture and fishing industries. By better understanding how fish defend these mucosal surfaces better tools to combat fish diseases can be developed.

Until recently it was thought that mucosal immunoglobulins evolved from tetrapod species. Breaking this paradigm, trout IgT was shown to be an immunoglobulin specialized in gut mucosal immunity and concurrently, a new B cell subset was described uniquely expressing IgT. These findings have led to hypothesize a key role for IgT in mucosal immunity supported by the large numbers of IgT+ B cells that accumulate at sites of infection in both the gut and the skin that are pathogen-specific immunoglobulin (IgT) responses. Curiously, the IgT+ B cells express the highest levels of IL-10 of any other leukocyte. IL-10 is a key anti-inflammatory cytokine. Based on the unanticipated high IL-10 producing capacity of IgT+ B cells, it is now hypothesized that these cells play novel immunoregulatory functions in both mucosal and systemic organs upon pathogenic challenge. As these cells are crucial for producing pathogen-specific mucosal IgT responses, it is also hypothesized that IgT+ B cells play a pivotal role in the control and/or clearance of pathogens in mucosal surfaces. Utilizing a novel IgT+ B cell-depletion fish model, the project presents aims to assess the mechanistic basis of the inflammatory and regulatory responses in the depleted fish upon pathogenic challenge. The pathogens chosen for this purpose infect either skin only, gut only or produce systemic infections. Thus the investigators will be able to evaluate the IgT+ B cell contribution to pathogen control and clearance in animals infected with the pathogens and they will use illumina high throughput transcriptome sequencing analysis following infection. These combined approaches will illuminate the role of IgT positive B cells in teleost fish with differing pathogenic challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fish species are primarily  protected from pathogens  by a set of molecules and cells that are present in their surfaces. These  surfaces are typically coated by a thin layer of mucus which contains a number of important immune molecules that fight pathogens. Such areas are termed as “mucosal surfaces”. Our laboratory discovered a few years ago that similar to mammalian species, fish contain an antibody molecule (IgT)  that is specialized to defend these mucosal surfaces. We also discovered a new cell type that produced these IgT antibodies, which are called IgT+ B cells. This project explored the main and unexplored roles of IgT and IgT+ B cells in protecting  fish mucosal surfaces. To evaluate these roles, we developed fish that lacked IgT+ B cells. These fish were also devoid of IgT in their mucosal surfaces, thus allowing us to understand the relevance of IgT in immune protection. Fish lacking IgT and IgT+ B cells were found to be significantly more susceptible to pathogens, thus demonstrating a key role of IgT in protecting fish mucosal surfaces. We also found that IgT played a crucial role in the maintenance of the beneficial bacterial species that typically inhabit vertebrate mucosal surfaces. Such bacterial species are collectively referred to as microbiota, and they play key roles in  metabolism and immunity among others. We found that fish lacking IgT  and IgT+ B cells contained a population of microbiota that was very different from the original one, and we found that bacterial species of their microbiota underwent significant changes in terms of their relative composition and abundance. The term to describe acute changes in these parameters  is called dysbiosis. Hence, fish lacking IgT underwent through a severe process of dysbiosis which led to the escape of some of these bacterial species into the surrounding fish tissues. This induced inflammation and tissue damage in these mucosal surfaces. In conclusion, these studies demonstrated that IgT is a crucial antibody molecule in mucosal surfaces where it plays a key role in the fight against pathogens, and at the same time, is responsible for the maintenance of a healthy population of microbiota. From an evolutionary viewpoint, these studies demonstrate that antibodies specialized in mucosal surfaces arose early in evolution, right after the emergence of bony vertebrates. Moreover our findings indicate that these mucosal antibodies evolved with the goal to both protect mucosal surfaces from pathogens, while maintaining a healthy microbiota population in the same areas. Because of the significance of these novel findings, these results were published this year in a highly reputed journal, Science Immunology, and they made the cover of the journal issue (see Fig. 1). Moreover, press releases from this publication appeared in several scientific and university news outlets, and were widely disseminated through social media, including twitter and facebook. Another important finding of our research was the discovery of a novel function played by IgT+ B cells in the way they kill cells. We discovered that these B cells contain a set of molecules called perforins, that are typically not present in vertebrate B cells. As the name indicates, perforins play a cytotoxic role by perforing the membrane of several cell types, including bacteria and cells that have been infected by viruses. This is an important discovery because it indicates that vertebrate B cells contain a previously unrecognized new function in immune defense. We hope to be to expand on these new findings in future research projects.  In addition to providing important new knowledge on the immune system of fish species and the understanding of the evolution of mucosal immunity in vertebrates, our new findings will also have an impact in the future development of fish vaccines that are capable of inducing protective mucosal responses. Thus far, such vaccines are lacking in the field of fish vaccinology, and we expect that the development of mucosal vaccines for fish will have a tremendous positive impact for the improvement of fish health for the  fish farm industry.

Critically, this project supported also a new research initiative in our laboratory called “Minority Research Support Initiative-Comparative Immunology Internship Competition (MRSI-CIIC)”. This initiative is meant to provide with research opportunities in comparative immunology to  underrepresented undergraduate students. During this project, three underrepresented undergraduate students benefited from that new initiative. Each student spent an 8 week period in our laboratory learning different laboratory techniques and being mentored in the field of comparative immunology. Moreover these students had the opportunity to experience and learn  how top-end research is performed in a highly ranked University, as well as to assist to immunology talks given by top world immunologists in our University on a weekly basis. Such an exposure is expected to  improve access and opportunities of these underrepresented students to research laboratories in the future, or other related professions.
